There's no need to get offensive guys, but I don't think you really get what Jackson has done here. He has re-written cinema standards. Very few IMAX theaters could even run the film at the intended 48 fps. Roughly speaking each image is 4mb, 4 x 48 x 2 = 384 (it's in 3D so each eye needs it's own image) That means 384 mb per sec to to processed and be thrown onto a 4k screen. Of course 48 fps looks much better, but only if every thing else, ie image resolution remains the same. Now your computer says it can run different frame rates, sure, but not at full rez, think about it, something has to give. You want to download what a 10 gb file? You can't have 48 fps, 1080p at that size without major compression. You will get a better copy running 24 fps than 48 fps with the resulting compression to each frame. Ultimately you cannot expect the same quality as IMAX from a downloaded ripped bluRay. Enjoy the movie, however you get to see it.

To all who want a 48fps release, its not likely to happen from a blue ray source due to the fact that blue ray does not support 48fps...  blue ray players likely wont have the processing power to decode 48fps.  Its hard to say if we will see a web version (itunes) since those tooo are unlikely to posess the power to decode video at 48fps smoothly with current codecs.

To the shit head confusing refresh rate and frame rate, they're not the same thing.  TV's are incapable of a frame rate higher than 30 frames per second (NTSC) and 25 frames per second (PAL).  Normally film is shot at 24 fps, The Hobbit is the first film to be shot at 48 fps.
